articles.headline: For Lehman, More Cuts and Anxiety
articles.snippet: Lehman Brothers, Wall Street’s most troubled firm, is preparing to lay off up to 1,500 people in its fourth round of cutbacks this year.
articles.abstract: Lehman Brothers, Wall Street’s most troubled firm, is preparing to lay off up to 1,500 people in its fourth round of cutbacks this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, the ax keeps falling again and again.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Putin Suggests U.S. Provocation in Georgia Clash
articles.snippet: Russia’s prime minister said he thought the U.S. might have helped “stir up” the conflict to benefit one of the presidential candidates.
articles.abstract: Russia’s prime minister said he thought the U.S. might have helped “stir up” the conflict to benefit one of the presidential candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As Russia struggled to rally international support for its military action in Georgia, Vladimir V. Putin, the country’s paramount leader, lashed out at the United States on Thursday, contending that the White House may have orchestrated the conflict to benefit one of the candidates in the American presidential election.

articles.headline: In Texas School, Teachers Carry Books and Guns
articles.snippet: A school board in north-central Texas has drawn attention by letting some teachers carry concealed weapons.
articles.abstract: A school board in north-central Texas has drawn attention by letting some teachers carry concealed weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARROLD, Tex. — Students in this tiny town of grain silos and ranch-style houses spent much of the first couple of days in school this week trying to guess which of their teachers were carrying pistols under their clothes.

articles.headline: Sense and Reality on Energy
articles.snippet: In 1974, the country had a president who actually wanted to confront the issue of high oil prices and the proposals made then seem highly relevant now.
articles.abstract: In 1974, the country had a president who actually wanted to confront the issue of high oil prices and the proposals made then seem highly relevant now.
articles.lead_paragraph: High oil prices have helped to bring down the American economy and to devastate Detroit. Politicians are talking about energy policy, although they seem to be talking past each other.

articles.headline: Worker Assets Shrink at Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: The employees of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are reeling as the companies lurch toward what could be a bailout.
articles.abstract: The employees of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are reeling as the companies lurch toward what could be a bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae’s workers had $116 million in the employee stock ownership plan at the end of 2006. Today, it’s more like $17.5 million. Ouch.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Bolivian Is an Uneasy Ally as U.S. Presses Drug War
articles.snippet: President Evo Morales, a former coca grower, is both a partner in U.S. anti-drug policy and an antagonist.
articles.abstract: President Evo Morales, a former coca grower, is both a partner in U.S. anti-drug policy and an antagonist.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHIMORÉ, Bolivia  The refrain here in the Chapare jungle about Americans is short but powerful: “Long Live Coca, Death to the Yanquis!”

articles.headline: AT&T’s Rivals Are Happy to Attack Over iPhone’s Network Woes
articles.snippet: The debut of Apple’s iPhone 3G cellphones has been a public relations headache for AT&T, after complaints of dropped calls and poor network connections.
articles.abstract: The debut of Apple’s iPhone 3G cellphones has been a public relations headache for AT&T, after complaints of dropped calls and poor network connections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple sold more than a million iPhone 3G cellphones its first weekend  with some stores running out  and two million more since then, analysts say. But its July debut has been nothing less than a public relations headache for AT&T, with eager buyers complaining about dropped calls and poor network connections.

articles.headline: Bringing Lofty Words Down to Earth
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama made his promise of “change” specific and showed he could fight his opponent.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama made his promise of “change” specific and showed he could fight his opponent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER  Good, great or something else, Senator Barack Obama’s acceptance speech Thursday night unquestionably confronted two of his greatest challenges.

articles.headline: Obama Takes the Fight to McCain
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama told tens of thousands of Democrats gathered at Invesco Field on Thursday night that he could repair “broken politics.”
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama told tens of thousands of Democrats gathered at Invesco Field on Thursday night that he could repair “broken politics.”
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER  Barack Obama accepted the Democratic Party presidential nomination on Thursday, declaring that the “American promise has been threatened” by eight years under President Bush and that John McCain represented a continuation of policies that undermined the nation’s economy and imperiled its standing around the world.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Alaskan Is McCain’s Choice; First Woman on G.O.P. Ticket
articles.snippet: In choosing Gov. Sarah Palin, John McCain reached far outside the Beltway and selected the Republicans’ first female vice presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: In choosing Gov. Sarah Palin, John McCain reached far outside the Beltway and selected the Republicans’ first female vice presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio  Senator John McCain astonished the political world on Friday by naming Sarah Palin, a little-known governor of Alaska and self-described “hockey mom” with almost no foreign policy experience, as his running mate on the Republican presidential ticket.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Elisabeth Bumiller
